title: Synthetic Recap
body:
LOS ANGELES — On a night where basketball felt secondary, the Great Western Forum bore witness to an offensive masterpiece for the ages. The final score, a 102-91 victory for the Seattle SuperSonics over the Los Angeles Lakers, was rendered almost meaningless. This was not merely a game; it was the Glenn Robinson Game.

From the opening tip, "Big Dog" was unleashed, putting on a scoring clinic that left the Lakers—and ultimately the record books—utterly defenseless. Robinson’s performance was one of breathtaking efficiency and relentless production, pouring in a staggering **52 points**. He attacked from every conceivable angle, a one-man offensive system that the star-studded Lakers, including Shaquille O’Neal, had no answer for.

While Shaq delivered a mighty 26 points and 18 rebounds of his own, his efforts were a footnote to Robinson’s historic night. The Lakers’ defense scrambled, switched, and doubled, but it was futile. Robinson was simply in a zone visited by only the game's elite, each basket another brushstroke on a career-defining canvas.

The Sonics, propelled by this singular force, methodically built their lead. Robinson’s 52 points did not just fuel the win; they demoralized an entire franchise and its roaring home crowd. Every possession was an event, a collective breath held to see what Robinson would do next.

In the end, the numbers told a story that words could scarcely capture. On this night in 1997, Glenn Robinson didn't just beat the Lakers; he authored a performance so dominant, so pure, that it transcended the contest itself, securing his place in the annals of NBA history.
